I'm not superstitious

    I am not superstitious. Only a blind person, one who is impaired both visually and intellectually would suffice to overwhelm their short graceful life with grand beliefs justified by trivial reasons. Must he not be a fool? Or is he so despicable that the only thing keeping him decent is divine intervention, the perpetual fear of the Lord’s wrath. Why would he suggest a misfortune to occur after crossing the path intersected by a black cat?

    Anyway, enough gibberish. I do not wish any negative energy engulfing me today, only blissful optimism, just like yesterday. And yesterday was amazing. Started out a little odd though with me brushing my teeth twice to give those whites a clean shine after I had a heavy breakfast. Then, I found a quick solution to a hurdle: my wet backpack, drenched by the incessant rain the day before, was effortlessly replaced by my brother’s cooler version, which was thankfully available, saving me the embarrassment of carrying my dad’s ancient book-holder with straps. Yesterday, I missed my bus as well but a benevolent guy viewing me distressed at the bus stop gave me a ride to school. Do you see now? This was how my day was rolling out. Monotonous troubles that were magically being resolved. It was like an antibody with binocular vision preparing beforehand to tackle a virus. You could almost sympathize for the cruel parasite. Oh, and did I tell you about how beautiful she looked. I watched her all day, yet all her moves were so unpredictable, and still are. How could she do all this? Eliciting a response of what I perceive as true love even though all our lengthy conversations have been a few seconds of casual greetings accompanied by that glistening smile of hers. I didn’t even know her that well. But, being an expert on myself, I definitely knew how I felt about her. So, with equal amount of courage and fear, I took a leap to exchange some dialogue to inquire what she thought of me: am a pervert whose vicious eyes discomfort her or a secret admirer she wishes to be revealed. Fortunately, all we did was talk instead of diving into the explanations of bewildering emotions. For the moment, whatever it was, it’s effect was splendorous. Talking to her felt great.

    Anyway, enough about yesterday. Today, I brushed my teeth twice again even though those whites didn’t need any additional cleansing. My backpack was completely dried up, yet I chose to lengthen the borrowing period by carrying on with my brother’s bag. He required it today, so I left the house early without even asking him for it. And now, it’s half past eight. I still have 30 minutes to reach my stop. No student would like to walk the long arduous road to school and on a day when I’m this early, the possibility of missing the bus is close to none. So, why are my feet slowing down, almost to the point of a complete stand still? Why do I want to miss my bus? Am I being so foolish as to think that repeating yesterday’s actions will yield in the same result; that wonderful scenario where I get to talk to her again. But I am not superstitious.
